docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Leonard T. Kurland, a neurologist who mined the science of epidemiology for techniques that led to new thinking about diseases in his field and others, died on Dec. 4 at his home in Rochester, Minn. He was 79. The cause was a heart attack, his family said.
docs.abstract: Dr Leonard T Kurland, neurologist, dies at 79; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A judge annulled a ruling that denied refugee status to the Mexican pop singer Gloria Trevi, who has been charged in Mexico with the sexual abuse of minors and who says her life would be in danger if she were turned over to the Mexican authorities. Brazil's refugee council ruled last month that she did not qualify as a refugee. The judge said the ruling was invalid because the council commented publicly on the case before officially judging it. Ms. Trevi, who was arrested in Brazil early last year and has been in jail ever since, is eight months pregnant and has told congressional investigators that she was raped by police officials. In the past, Brazilian law has prevented the extradition of a foreigner who is the parent of a Brazilian child.

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Another Twist In Trevi Case

docs.abstract: Brazilian court annuls ruling that denied refugee status to Mexican pop singer Gloria Trevi, who has been charged in Mexico with sexual abuse of minors and who says her life would be in danger if she were turned over to Mexican authorities; Trevi, who was arrested in Brazil early last year and has been in jail ever since, is eight month pregnant and has told investigators that she was raped by police officials; in past, Brazilian law has prevented extradition of foreigner who is parent of Brazilian child; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The South African government announced today that it will appeal a court decision ordering the government to come up with a plan for widespread distribution of a low-cost anti-AIDS drug for newborn babies. A spokeswoman for the country's Health Department said the High Court in Pretoria had exceeded the authority of the judicial system when Judge Chris Botha ruled last week that pregnant H.I.V.-positive women under state care are entitled to the drug, nevirapine, which has found to effective in reducing the risk of mother-to-child transmission of the virus that causes AIDS.

headline.main: South Africa to Appeal Ruling Ordering Access to AIDS Drug

docs.abstract: South African government says it will appeal court decision ordering it to come up with plan for widespread distribution of nevirapine, drug used to reduce risk of mother-to-child transmission of AIDS virus (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The residents came to the high school this evening hoping to hear reassuring certainties from state and federal scientists who have examined local fears that the community's high rates of childhood cancers were caused by pollution from industrial sites here. What they got was the carefully hedged finding that only one kind of cancer might be due to contaminated wells and industrial air pollution, and the conclusion that no explanation exists for the other cancers that have stricken children in this shore town.

headline.main: Little Reassurance for Toms River Residents About Causes of Cancers

docs.abstract: Toms River, New Jersey, get little reassurance from federal and state officials with regard to high rates of childhood cancers in community; photo; scientists say no single environmental factor appears to be responsible, and that some of cancers have no discernible link to water or air pollution from two Superfund sites; strongest link involves female babies of mothers who consumed water contaminated by Ciba-Geigy site (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the waning hours of Republican control of the State Legislature, New Jersey lawmakers today revived a proposed constitutional amendment requiring parental notification for minors seeking abortions and voted to require sex-education classes to emphasize abstinence. Both of the measures were long sought by conservatives and had been rebuffed by the Legislature and the State Supreme Court.

headline.main: Push Resumes For Notifying Parents Of Abortions

docs.lead_paragraph: Our government is now committed to large-scale production of smallpox vaccine as a defense against bioterrorism, but not committed to letting Americans choose to be vaccinated. The plan is to provide vaccines only to those in high-risk groups and to medical workers. For all others, vaccine would be stockpiled until smallpox appeared and then given in a flurry of urgency. If fears of an attack using smallpox turn out to be much ado about nothing, this approach will have saved Americans from the vaccine's side effects. But what if there is an attack? A fully unvaccinated population could face dangers that would not be easy to control with the crisis approach. But if Americans were given the choice beforehand, when such an attack came many probably would already be vaccinated.

headline.main: A Risky Policy On Smallpox Vaccinations

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Paul W Ewald, biology professor, disagrees with United States government plan to provide smallpox vaccines only to those in high-risk groups and medical workers, and to stockpile rest of vaccine until smallpox appears; says better idea is to give all Americans choice to be vaccinated beforehand; says fully unvaccinated population could face dangers that would not be easy to control with this crisis approach; says if Americans are given choice beforehand, when such an attack comes many probably would already be vaccinated; says voluntary vaccination would give Americans some power to protect themselves while helping to deter attack; diagram (M)
docs.snippet: Our government is now committed to large-scale production of smallpox vaccine as a defense against bioterrorism, but not committed to letting Americans choose to be vaccinated. The plan is to provide vaccines only to those in high-risk groups and to...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE last two years have made spectacularly clear what the legacy of the decade-long economic expansion will not be. The coming year should go a long way toward determining what its legacy really will be. The boom did not rewrite the rules for valuing stocks, as many investors had thought less than two years ago. It did not promise a future without recessions, as many boosters were still predicting a year ago. It did not even herald the start of a new era of government surpluses, as nearly all analysts had expected earlier this year.

headline.main: Economy & Business; A Bruised Economy Leaves Everyone Guessing

docs.abstract: Bruised national economy has uncertain future; decade-long economic expansion has not rewritten rules for valuing stocks or promise a future without recessions or herald new era of government surpluses; time will tell whether robust growth in 1990's was aberration or signal of new normalcy (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Group Plans Asian College for Women in Poverty'' (news article, Dec. 9): Educating low-income Asian women and girls is a wise investment that will pay off in economic and health terms for the students, their future families and their societies.

docs.lead_paragraph: For 30 years the gap between the richest Americans and everyone else has been growing so much that the level of inequality is higher than in any other industrialized nation. What no one can quite figure out, though, is why, or even whether anything should be done about it.
docs.abstract: Gap between richest Americans and everyone else has grown so much in past 30 years that level of inequality is higher than in any other industrialized nation; economists have largely come to see this inequality as basic feature of new high-tech economic scene, natural consequence of economy that increasingly rewards talent, skill and risktaking; where many economists split, however, is over whether anything should be done about the divide (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a rebuke of South Africa's AIDS policy, a judge ruled today that pregnant women under state care who are H.I.V. infected are entitled to a low-cost drug that has been found to reduce a newborn's risk of contracting the virus. The decision by Judge Chris Botha of the Pretoria High Court was praised by advocacy groups, which have accused President Thabo Mbeki and his government of moving too slowly in dealing with mother-to-child transmission of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

headline.main: South African Court Orders Medicine for H.I.V.-Infected Mothers
